intro: Galium spurium f. strigosum, commonly known as the hairy bedstraw, is a low-growing perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, prostrate stems covered in fine, whitish hairs. The plant produces small, white or pale green flowers in clusters, typically blooming from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to elliptic in shape, and often have a slightly hairy texture. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
